Dear Dan 

I'm not really sure that I understand the concept of a negative
=
prefactor, however this might be a fix:
A negative prefactor should result =
in a a negative rate constant.
According to the principle of microscopic re=
versiblility 

k_b =3D k_f/K_eq 

, where K_eq is the equilibirum constant =
for an elementary reaction
step and k_f and k_b are the forward and backwar=
d rate constants,
respectively. Since K_eq can not be negavtive (at least f=
rom my
knowledge of basic statistical thermodynamics) a negative k_a would
=
result in k_b being negative as well. For a simple reaction, say,

a + b =
=3D c

the rate equation is:

r =3D k_f *[a]*[b] - k_b[c]

Changing the sig=
n of both k_f and k_b 

r =3D -k_f *[a]*[b] + k_b*[c]

This is actually equ=
al to the rate equation of the reverse reaction.
Thus, in my point of view =
a negative prefactor is just a "cover up" of
the fact that the reaction was=
 written up in the wrong direction. 
Does this make any sense, or have I co=
mpletely missed the point here?

Kind regards

Anders   

--- In cantera@ya=
hoogroups.com, "Dan Smyth" <das69@...> wrote:
>
> Hi,
> 
> I have successfu=
lly installed Cantera onto my Linux box and am trying
> to replace numerous=
 Chemkin subroutines in a code of mine with
> corresponding Cantera calls. =
 I have translated a mechanism from the
> Chemkin format into Cantera forma=
t by using the ck2cti program with
> the verification option and seemed to =
pass.  I'm calling
> getNetProductionRates(wdot) from my program and am get=
ting "nan" in
> return for seven different species.  I have tracked the pro=
blem by
> calling:
> 
> getFwdRatesOfProgress
> getRevRatesOfProgress
> get=
FwdRateConstants
> getRevRateConstants
> 
> and have found that there are t=
wo reactions in my mechanism that are
> returning a "nan" value.  They are =
both reactions that have been
> declared as duplicate reactions and they al=
so both have negative
> pre-exponentials.  (These are the only reactions in=
 my mechanism that
> have a negative pre-exponential.)  My original Chemkin=

> DUP

> As far as I can tell everything has bee=
n converted correctly.  From
> what I have found by looking around the avai=
lable Cantera literature,
> the only way that a negative pre-exponential fa=
ctor can be used inside
> Cantera is for it to be declared as part of a dup=
licate reaction, be
> declared as having the option negative_A, and have th=
e total overall
> rate be positive.  Something is happening here though, as=
 the even the
> rate coefficients are being returned as "nan" values.  This=
 is
> consistent with both the forward and reverse coefficients, and
> obvi=
ously the forward and reverse rates of progress.  Am I
> understanding all =
this correctly?
> 
> As far as I can tell, I'm within the parameters set by=
 Cantera to use
> negative pre-exponential factors, but I'm getting these b=
ogus values
> in return, and am not sure (what to do)/(what to check) next.=
  Do you
> know what might be wrong?  Is there something else that I can ch=
eck to
> make sure that I'm doing things right?  Thanks.
> 
> Dan Smyth
